prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Turquoise -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Turquoise

data.sampled:
BB (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/2 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green)

Explanation:
Since this is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles (B, G, and T) and dominant inheritance pattern (B > G > T), we can determine the possible outcomes of this cross.

The parents have two different alleles, B (blue) and G (green), so they are heterozygous at this locus. The F1 generation will have four offspring:

* B Blue (25%)
* BG (50%)
* G Green (25%)

The genotype of the offspring is determined by the alleles inherited from each parent. For example:

* If both parents pass the blue allele to offspring, the resulting genotype will be BB, blue (25%)
* If one parent passes blue (B), and the other passes green (G), the resulting genotype will be BG, blue (50%)
* If the offspring receives the green allele from both parents, the resulting genotype will be GG, green (25%)

In this cross, the parents are BB (blue) and BG (blue-green), meaning they have Blue allele (B) and Green allele (G), respectively. This will result in an F1 generation with 50% B blue offspring, and 50% BG blue-green offspring.

Example task:

Example Task:

data.sampled:
A polymorphic population of a new type of beetle can have one of three possible color variations for their wings: blue, green, or turquoise. These variations are due to the presence of different alleles of a gene: B, G, or T, respectively. When individuals with different alleles mate, their offspring may inherit any of the three possible color variations.

In a monohybrid cross, two individuals with different alleles are crossed to produce a new generation of offspring with a single dominant trait. For example, in a cross between a blue-winged beetle and a green-winged beetle, the dominant trait will be blue, and the F1 generation offspring will all have blue wings. The distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation can be expected to be 3:1 in favor of blue.

In the same way, you can calculate the expected distribution of phenotypes for crossing two beetles of the same color. For example, two green-winged beetles will produce an F1 generation with 1/4 BB (4 blue-winged beetles), 1/2 BG (6 blue- and green-winged beetles), and 1/4 GG (4 green-winged beetles), for a total of 11 offspring.

To find the genotypes of the offspring, you'll need to consider dominant and recessive alleles. For example, in the cross between two green-winged beetles, the expected distribution of phenotypes is 3:1 in favor of green. Thus, the F1 generation offspring will all have either BG or GG genotypes. The BG genotype will give them green wings, while the GG genotype will give them blue wings.

data.sampled:
The genotypes of the parents and offspring are:

Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue (B_B) 1/4 Green (B_g)

The distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation is the result of a monohybrid inheritance with the dominance of B over G and T. The genotypes in the F1 generation are the result of the crossing of two blue beetles which both carry the B allele, but do not necessarily express it due to dominance.

The phenotype ratio in the offspring is 3 to 1 (Blue to Green) due to the dominance of blue over green. The genotype ratio is expected to be approximately 1:3:3 (B_B: B_g: G_G), based on the probabilities of dominant, heterozygous, and recessive homozygous genotypes.

So the phenotype probability for this monohybrid inheritance is 1 Blue phenotype (3/4 of the F1 generation). And the remaining offspring will have either 1 Blue or 1 green phenotype (1/4 of the offspring)

Please note that in real populations there can be other genetic variations that could affect the inheritance pattern, or external factors that could affect the distribution, making the result possibly different from what I just described.
